There are limits on the types of work and hours teens can do. But don’t worry – plenty of options exist for young teens to make some cash. I first started making money around this age, and I absolutely loved it. Being able to make my own money and buy things on my own felt great, and I also learned so much about money management as well as became more confident in life. Recommended reading: 23 Business Ideas For Teens To Make Extra Money Can a 13 year old work legally? Kids can work some jobs, but there are rules to make sure they stay safe and have plenty of time for school and fun. In the U.S., kids under 14 can’t work most jobs, but there are a few things they’re allowed to do, like babysitting, delivering newspapers, or acting in a show or movie. There are also rules about how many hours kids can work. For example, on school days, they may only be able to work up to 3 hours, but on weekends and holidays, they might work as long as 8 hours. These limits help them stay healthy and keep up with school. Check the rules in your area since they can be different from place to place. Always: Make sure parents or guardians know what the 13-year-old is doing. Have them work with people you know and trust. Have a trusted adult close by. It’s important to make sure the teenager knows they can always reach out to their guardian or parent for support without feeling uncomfortable or hesitant. You want them to feel safe and open, knowing they can discuss any concerns that may come up (for example, maybe the person they are working for has said something weird or uncomfortable to them). This way, if something doesn’t feel right – like a situation with a person they’re working for – they’ll know they can ask questions and, if necessary, step away from the job. Babysitting Babysitting can be an ideal job for a responsible 13-year-old, allowing them to earn money while helping families in the community. Many parents seek trustworthy sitters, making it a great opportunity. The pay for babysitting is often quite good, typically ranging from $10 to $20 per hour, which can add up quickly, especially on weekends or during school breaks. To help them find babysitting jobs, you might reach out to friends or neighbors who may know families looking for sitters. Before they begin, it’s very helpful for them to learn basic childcare skills and CPR. A babysitting course or first aid class can give them confidence and make parents feel more at ease hiring them. Babysitting can be one of the best ways to build responsibility and earn money. I remember how proud I felt after my first babysitting job, knowing I had made a real difference for a family and earned my own money. I was a young teenager at the time, and I was working around 36 hours a week during the summers as a full-time babysitter making $10 an hour, and it added up really fast! I actually opened up my first bank account (with a parent) due to that job, and it taught me a lot about money. 2. Dog walking Dog walking can be a wonderful job for a 13-year-old who loves animals, allowing them to earn money while spending time with pets. Dog walkers take dogs on walks around the neighborhood, helping keep the dogs healthy and happy while their owners are busy, such as when they are at work or on vacation. They could charge around $5 to $15 per dog per walk, with the potential to earn more as they take on multiple clients. I recently read a flyer on a local board from a young kid offering dog walking for about $5 per 30-minute session, with their parent accompanying them to help out. It seemed like a simple and fun way for the child to learn the basics of earning money and gain some responsibility, which I thought was really nice! 3. Lemonade stand A lemonade stand is a fun way for a 13-year-old to make money. They can set up a small table in the front yard or at a busy spot. They’ll need lemons, sugar, water, cups, and a pitcher to make lemonade. Plus, adding ice is a good idea on hot days to keep the drinks cool. Making a bright sign can help attract people’s attention. They could price the lemonade at 50 cents or $1 per cup. Adding snacks like cookies can also bring in more customers. Running a lemonade stand is a classic way to learn the basics of business in a fun, friendly way. They don’t need much to get started, which is nice – they’ll need basic items like soap, sponges, buckets, and towels. A hose can also help if customers don’t have one. They could team up with friends to wash more cars. This makes the job more fun and helps them finish faster. They can also split the money they earn. 6. House cleaning House cleaning can be a great way for a 13-year-old to earn money. They can start by helping family members or neighbors with easy tasks. These tasks might include dusting, vacuuming, or organizing rooms. They could also offer to clean windows, mop floors, or tidy up messy spaces. 7. They can start by offering tutoring to friends, family, or neighbors. Many parents look for affordable tutors for their kids. Online tutoring is another option. For example, they should wear closed-toe shoes and watch out for rocks or sticks. They can charge about $15 to $30 per lawn, depending on the size. Bigger yards take more time, so they can ask for more money. Summer is the busiest time for lawn care in many areas. They might mow the same yards every week or two because the grass grows so quickly, which means that they can have consistent jobs and customers. 9. This job works well if you live somewhere with a lot of snow. Many people, like older adults or busy families, are happy to pay for snow removal. They can charge by the job or set an hourly rate. I had many friends when I was growing up who would go in groups of 2 or 3 and knock on neighbors’ doors to see if they could get any customers. Or, sometimes they would have parents go with them to make sure everyone was safe too. 10. Errand running Errand running and doing chores can be a good way for a 13-year-old to make money. They can help neighbors and family friends with tasks they don’t have time for. Some errands they might do include returning library books, picking up dry cleaning, taking out trash cans to the curb, doing laundry, other light housekeeping, and more. 11. Some camps hire 13-year-olds, especially if they’ve been campers there before. They might help set up activities or watch over younger kids during free time. I have several friends who were junior camp counselors when they were younger. They went to the camp when they were kids and then applied, when they were old enough to work, at the same camps they attended when they were younger. They all loved it! 15.
